"SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE." The Congress finds that the Brown v. Board of Education decision was significant, the admission of the Little Rock Nine was a key example of its implementation, and Central High School is recognized for its architectural beauty. Central High School, recognized for its architectural beauty, was designated a national historic landmark in 1982 for its role in the civil rights movement. The school's inclusion in the National Park System aims to preserve and interpret its significance in the desegregation of Southern schools. The purpose of this Act is to educate and inspire present and future generations. Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas played a significant role in the integration of public schools and the civil rights movement in the United States. Its purpose is to educate and inspire present and future generations. Establishment of Central High School National Historic Site. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as a unit of the National Park System in Arkansas. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the site in accordance with relevant laws. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private agencies for the Little Rock Central High School historic site. A general management plan must be prepared within 2 years, and educational use will continue with consultation. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands within the historic site with consent of the owner, and only by donation or exchange for lands owned by the State of Arkansas or its subdivisions. Consultation with the Little Rock School District is required to ensure educational use of Central High School is not disrupted. SEC. 3. DESEGREGATION IN PUBLIC EDUCATION THEME STUDY. The Secretary is required to conduct a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education, identifying key sites and preparing a list of potential new national historic landmarks. This study aims to provide opportunities for education and research in this area. The theme study will establish linkages between key sites related to desegregation in public education and recommend cooperative arrangements with various entities to preserve and interpret these sites. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions and organizations knowledgeable about desegregation. The theme study for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site will be prepared in coordination with the general management plan. It will establish linkages between key sites related to desegregation in public education and recommend cooperative arrangements with entities knowledgeable about desegregation. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary to carry out this Act can be appropriated.
